topic_metadata.title: Any Possible OCR options in Typst like Mathpix in Latex?

posts.name: Chris Li
posts.cooked: As a student working on Mathematics and some TCS, I had used Latex quite a while before I started to try Typst. I like the features of Typst. But in latex, I get used to utilize OCR tools like mathpix to copy and paste the online formats. I haven’t seen any reliable alternative in Typst that is easy for ordinary usage. Are there possible alternative ways besides using latex-ocr then translating them into typst?
posts.raw: As a student working on Mathematics and some TCS, I had used Latex quite a while before I started to try Typst. I like the features of Typst. But in latex, I get used to utilize OCR tools like mathpix to copy and paste the online formats. I haven't seen any reliable alternative in Typst that is easy for ordinary usage. Are there possible alternative ways besides using latex-ocr then translating them into typst?

posts.name: baptiste
posts.cooked: Since the available training set (arXiv notably) is much larger in the TeX world, I imagine the best solution for now might be to rely on latex-ocr, but maybe augment it with a call to pandoc (via its Python library) to convert the output to typst automatically. I don’t know enough about Python packaging, but I would imagine it’s not too involved.
posts.raw: Since the available training set (arXiv notably) is much larger in the TeX world, I imagine the best solution for now might be to rely on `latex-ocr`, but maybe augment it with a call to pandoc (via its Python library) to convert the output to typst automatically. I don't know enough about Python packaging, but I would imagine it's not too involved.

posts.name: Kevio
posts.cooked:
There’s this: GitHub - detypstify/detypstify: Using OCR to convert images of formulas into Typst code. / Detypstify though I have not personally tried it yet.

For handwriting recognition of individual symbols, there’s: https://detypify.quarticcat.com/.
posts.raw:
There's this: https://github.com/detypstify/detypstify / https://detypstify.github.io/detypstify/ though I have not personally tried it yet.

For handwriting recognition of individual symbols, there's: https://detypify.quarticcat.com/.

posts.name: Eric Biedert
posts.cooked: There is also typress with a demo on huggingface which can do full equations.
posts.raw: There is also [typress](https://github.com/ParaN3xus/typress) with a [demo on huggingface](https://huggingface.co/spaces/paran3xus/typress_ocr_space) which can do full equations.

posts.name: Esteban Muñoz
posts.cooked:
github.com

GitHub - ParaN3xus/typress: Typst Mathematical Expression OCR

Typst Mathematical Expression OCR

Typress allows you to use images to get math formulas written in Typst. Haven’t used it yet, but in case you want to test it, the people behind it also have a demo in HuggingFace
posts.raw:
https://github.com/ParaN3xus/typress

Typress allows you to use images to get math formulas written in Typst. Haven't used it yet, but in case you want to test it, the people behind it also have a demo in [HuggingFace](https://huggingface.co/spaces/paran3xus/typress_ocr_space)

posts.name: Chris Li
posts.cooked: Truly Appriciate! I will try to use typress and detypstify. Just wish there can be a fast short-cut like control + command + m.
posts.raw: Truly Appriciate! I will try to use typress and **[detypstify](https://github.com/detypstify/detypstify)**. Just wish there can be a fast short-cut like control + command + m.

posts.name: Syzygy
posts.cooked:
For Typress, I often use this web app

https://typress-web.vercel.app/
posts.raw:
For Typress, I often use this web app 

https://typress-web.vercel.app/

posts.name: ParaN3xus
posts.cooked:
Hello, I am the developer of Typress. Currently, Typress has good support for printed formulas (such as textbook photos, screen captures, etc.), but support for handwritten formulas is still being improved.

Please note that Typress only supports mathematical formulas, unlike Mathpix, which also supports text mixed with formulas. Also, we do not have a mathematical formula recognition model, so if you use Typress, it is best to input images that contain only the formulas themselves, without any extraneous parts.
posts.raw:
Hello, I am the developer of Typress. Currently, Typress has good support for printed formulas (such as textbook photos, screen captures, etc.), but support for handwritten formulas is still being improved. 

Please note that Typress only supports mathematical formulas, unlike Mathpix, which also supports text mixed with formulas. Also, we do not have a mathematical formula recognition model, so if you use Typress, it is best to input images that contain only the formulas themselves, without any extraneous parts.

posts.name: Chris Li
posts.cooked: It’s so nice to hear from you! I’m glad to try it.
posts.raw: It's so nice to hear from you! I'm glad to try it.
